org.sliderule.stats

Class StudentsT

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.sliderule.stats.StudentsT

  • public final class StudentsT
extends java.lang.Object

    Student's t-Distribution

    This class provides a time-efficient means for querying values and inverse values from the cumulative distribution function (CDF) of Student's t-distribution. Also provided is a method to find the bounds(int, double, double, double) for a given confidence interval as well as a method to test(int, double, double, double) sample statistics - i.e. perform Student's t-test.

    Note, the test(int, double, double, double) is not sufficient to show that the random variable approximately described by sample statistics is actually Normal. For that purpose, Please see ChiSquared.

    See Also:
    • Wikipedia: Student's t-distribution
    • Chapra, Steven C., and Canale, Raymond P. Numerical Methods for Engineers, 4th Ed. Toronto: McGraw-Hill, 2002. pp 435. Print.
    • DeGroot, Morris H., and Schervish, Mark J. Probability and Statistics, 3rd Ed. Toronto: Addison-Wesley, 2002. pp. 404-416,776-777. Print.

    • Method Detail

      • cdf

        public static double cdf(int n,
         double x)
        Evaluate the cumulative distribution function of the StudentsT distribution.
        Parameters:
        n - sample size such that there are n-1 degrees of freedom. 2 <= n
        x - value of random variable X
        Returns:
        p = Pr( X <= x | n-1 )

      • inv

        public static double inv(int n,
         double p)
        Evaluate the inverse of the cumulative distribution function of the StudentsT distribution.
        Parameters:
        n - sample size such that there are n-1 degrees of freedom.2 <= n
        p - level of confidence. 0 <= p <= 1
        Returns:
        x ∋ Pr( X <= x | n-1 ) = p

      • bounds

        public static double[] bounds(int n,
              double p,
              double u,
              double o)
        Determine the confidence interval for sample statistics, assuming that the random variable they approximately describe is Normal.
        Parameters:
        n - sample size such that there are n-1 degrees of freedom. 2 <= n
        p - level of confidence. 0 <= p <= 1
        u - sample mean.
        o - sample variance.
        Returns:
        [ L, U ] ∈ Pr( L <= u <= U ) >= p

      • test

        public static boolean test(int n,
           double p,
           double u,
           double o)

        Test sample statistics for a given confidence level, assuming that the random variable they approximately describe is Normal.

        Parameters:
        n - sample size such that there are n-1 degrees of freedom. 2 <= n
        p - level of confidence. 0 <= p <= 1
        u - sample mean.
        o - sample variance.
        Returns:
        [ L, U ] ∈ Pr( L <= u <= U ) >= p
